724166f-a.text:
Washington Street, north from Barrow Street, showing mainly the cleared west side of this thoroughfare. Upon same will be erected the elevated roadbed of the New York Central Railroad that extends from the St. Johns Park Freight Terminal and continues up the west side of Manhattan.

The low buildings to the left are on the north side of Christopher Street, lying between Washington and Weehawken
(extreme left) Streets.

View No. 3 emphasizes this feature mainly. The tall
smokestacks are those of the Boadleston and Woerz Brewery
(q.v.) which was razed in the Summer of 1938.

Returning to View 1, one sees at the right margin a
portion of the U. S. Government building listed as the
Appraisers Stores.

The Everards Storage Warehouse is to the north, same being the 12 story structure bearing No. 667 Washington Street and located at the N.E. corner of W. 10th Street.
September 24, 1930
Views: 1-2-3
724166f-a.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724166f-b.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724167f-a.text:
(1)
St. Veronica'e Parochial Soheol, Washington Street at the S.W. corner of Barrow Street, seen from the N.E. corner.
July 25, 1930.
L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, three months later, showing the Barrow Street side
across the cleared N.W. corner.
September 26, 1930.
L. Sperr.
724167f-a.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724167f-b.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724165f-a.text:
Washington Street, north from Barrow Street, showing pavement subsequent to tract removal and prior to repavement. At the right is a portion of the U.S.Appraisers Stores Building occupying the frontage to Christopher Street. To the left is the elevated roadbed of the N.Y.C.R.R. Company.
April 26, 1937
W.P.A.Photo
Five Boroughs Project
724165f-a.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724168f-b.text:
(1) and (2)
634 to 648 Washington Street, west side, north from Barrow (left)
to Christopher (right) Streets, showing a row of old structures
prior to demolition for the elevated roadbed of the N.Y.C.R.R.
View 2 shows the property at the south west corner of Christopher
Street and upon which it bears No. 152 (also No. 648 Washington Street).
The distinctive smoke stacks shown across are of the Beadleston
and Woerz Brewery (demolished Summer 1938).
July 25, 1939.
P.L.Sperr
724168f-b.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724168f-a.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

716479f-b.text:
Barrow Street, at and west of Washington Street; the view is
northwest across the clearing on the S.W. corner, where St. Veronica's
parochial school has just been demolished. On the north side is
shown the rear of the newly built Christopher Street Garage, Parmelee
Transportation Company (the yellow cabs).
December 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
716479f-b.folder: Barrow Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

716480f-a.text:
Barrow Street, adjoining and at the N.W. corner of Washington
Street, after demolition of the Barrow Street Garage, 142-130
Barrow Street.
June 15, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
716480f-a.folder: Barrow Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724164f-a.text:
Washington Street, west side, from Barrow Street to and including
Morton Street, cleared for construction of the railroad's
elevated roadbed.
July 16, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
724164f-a.folder: Washington Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY
